elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Six new complexes constructed by 5-sulfosalicylic acid and bipyridyl-like ligands, namely, [Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(phen)4 ⋅7H2O] 1, [Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(bipy)4 ⋅2H2O] 2, [Cd(Hssal)(bipy)] 3, [Cd(HL)2(phen)2] 4, [Cr(ssal)(bipy)(H2O)2 ⋅2H2O] 5 and [Cr(ssal)(phen)2] 6, were prepared under hydrothermal conditions. The results of magnetic determination show that ferromagnetic interactions exist in complex 1, however, antiferromagnetic interactions exist in 2. Complexes 3 and 4 exhibit intense green and blue photoluminescence, respectively.

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) and [Cr(ssal)(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>ssal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-sulfosalicylic acid, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid, bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′-bipy, phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,10-phen) were prepared under hydrothermal conditions and their structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are both tetranuclear copper complexes with a stepped topology. In complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, a new coordination mode of the Hssal<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> group is reported in this work. During the synthetic process of complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> decarboxylation of 5-sulfosalicylic acid into <ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid is involved. Two chromium 5-sulfosalicylates (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) are reported for the first time. These new complexes display different supramolecular structures by O–H⋯O, C–H⋯O hydrogen bonds as well as π⋯π, C–H⋯π and O⋯π interactions. The results of magnetic determination show that ferromagnetic interactions exist in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, however, antiferromagnetic interactions exist in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Six new complexes constructed by 5-sulfosalicylic acid and bipyridyl-like ligands (2,2'-bipy and 1,10-phen), namely [Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(phen)4 ⋅7H2O] (1), [Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(bipy)4 ⋅2H2O] (2), [Cd(Hssal)(bipy)] (3), [Cd(HL)2(phen)2] (4), [Cr(ssal)(bipy)(H2O)2 ⋅2H2O] (5) and [Cr(ssal)(phen)2] (6) (H3ssal=5-sulfosalicylic acid, H2L= p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid, bipy=2,2'-bipy, phen=1,10-phen) were prepared under hydrothermal conditions and their structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complexes 1 and 2 are both tetranuclear copper complexes with a stepped topology. In complex 3, a new coordination mode of the Hssal2- group is reported in this work. During the synthetic process of complex 4, in situ decarboxylation of 5-sulfosalicylic acid into p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid is involved. Two chromium 5-sulfosalicylates (5 and 6) are reported for the first time. These new complexes display different supramolecular structures by O-H⋯O, C-H⋯O hydrogen bonds as well as π⋯π, C-H⋯π and O⋯π interactions. The results of magnetic determination show that ferromagnetic interactions exist in complex 1, however, antiferromagnetic interactions exist in 2.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Since 1989, the definition of crystal engineering was provided by G.R. Desiraju as “the understanding of intermolecular interactions in the context of crystal packing and in the utilization of such understanding in the design of new solids with desired physical and chemical properties” . The rational design and construction of novel supramolecular materials based on discrete or polymeric metal–organic coordination complexes have garnered considerable interest owing to their intriguing topologies and potential for use as functional materials . An important synthetic method for design and tailor-making of such supramolecular materials utilizes suitable organic ligands that can coordinate to metal ions through one or more primary coordination sites, whilst at the same time can participate in additional bonding interactions (hydrogen bonding or other molecular contacts) at peripheral sites. An advantage of this method is that it may combine the flexibility of the weaker interactions with the strength of coordination bonding. This method has been widely employed in poly-carboxylate ligands, which have proven to be particularly effective in the formation of both extended hydrogen bonded networks and coordination complexes . The choice of 5-sulfosalicylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>ssal) can be attributed to the following reasons: (1) it possesses versatile coordination modes (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig19"></ce:float-anchor>) and has the ability to construct a novel metal–organic supramolecular network through specific and directional hydrogen bonds as well as π–π stacking due to the presence of aryl rings , (2) 5-sulfosalicylic acid has been found to have biological activity and its metal complexes with Cu(II), Ni(II), Co(II), Mn(II), Fe(II), Zn(II) and VO(II) exhibit antimicrobial activity stronger than that of the free ligand . In order to avoid the formation of higher dimensional coordination networks, polycyclic aromatic chelating ligands such as 2,2′-bipyridyl (2,2′-bipy) and 1,10-phenanthroline (1,10-phen) were introduced based on the following considerations: (1) chelating bipyridyl-like ligands may provide supramolecular recognition sites for π–π, C–H⋯π stacking and C–H⋯O hydrogen bonding to form interesting supramolecular structures , (2) the conjugated π systems containing (hetero) aromatic rings are currently of interests in the development of fluorescent materials .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since 1989, the definition of crystal engineering was provided by G.R. Desiraju as "the understanding of intermolecular interactions in the context of crystal packing and in the utilization of such understanding in the design of new solids with desired physical and chemical properties" . The rational design and construction of novel supramolecular materials based on discrete or polymeric metal-organic coordination complexes have garnered considerable interest owing to their intriguing topologies and potential for use as functional materials . An important synthetic method for design and tailor-making of such supramolecular materials utilizes suitable organic ligands that can coordinate to metal ions through one or more primary coordination sites, whilst at the same time can participate in additional bonding interactions (hydrogen bonding or other molecular contacts) at peripheral sites. An advantage of this method is that it may combine the flexibility of the weaker interactions with the strength of coordination bonding. This method has been widely employed in poly-carboxylate ligands, which have proven to be particularly effective in the formation of both extended hydrogen bonded networks and coordination complexes . The choice of 5-sulfosalicylic acid (H3ssal) can be attributed to the following reasons: (1) it possesses versatile coordination modes ( ) and has the ability to construct a novel metal-organic supramolecular network through specific and directional hydrogen bonds as well as π-π stacking due to the presence of aryl rings , (2) 5-sulfosalicylic acid has been found to have biological activity and its metal complexes with Cu(II), Ni(II), Co(II), Mn(II), Fe(II), Zn(II) and VO(II) exhibit antimicrobial activity stronger than that of the free ligand . In order to avoid the formation of higher dimensional coordination networks, polycyclic aromatic chelating ligands such as 2,2'-bipyridyl (2,2'-bipy) and 1,10-phenanthroline (1,10-phen) were introduced based on the following considerations: (1) chelating bipyridyl-like ligands may provide supramolecular recognition sites for π-π, C-H⋯π stacking and C-H⋯O hydrogen bonding to form interesting supramolecular structures , (2) the conjugated π systems containing (hetero) aromatic rings are currently of interests in the development of fluorescent materials .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In order to understand the coordination chemistry of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>ssal and to prepare new supramolecular materials with intriguing structures and potential physical properties, we have recently focused our research on coordination complexes based on 5-sulfosalicylic acid and chelating bipyridyl-like ligands. Here, we report the syntheses and crystal structures of six new complexes, namely,[Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ssal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ssal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [Cd(Hssal)(bipy)] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), [Cd(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), [Cr(ssal)(bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) and [Cr(ssal)(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>), together with the magnetic properties of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The crystal structures of complexes Mn(Hssal)(bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>)  and Zn(Hssal)(bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>)  were reported previously. The results demonstrate that the discrete or polymeric complexes may build up higher network connectivity through π–π stacking, C–H⋯π, O⋯π and hydrogen-bonding interactions including weak C–H⋯O contacts.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In order to understand the coordination chemistry of H3ssal and to prepare new supramolecular materials with intriguing structures and potential physical properties, we have recently focused our research on coordination complexes based on 5-sulfosalicylic acid and chelating bipyridyl-like ligands. Here, we report the syntheses and crystal structures of six new complexes, namely,[Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(phen)4 ⋅7H2O] (1), [Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(bipy)4 ⋅2H2O] (2), [Cd(Hssal)(bipy)] (3), [Cd(HL)2(phen)2] (4), [Cr(ssal)(bipy)(H2O)2 ⋅2H2O] (5) and [Cr(ssal)(phen)2] (6), together with the magnetic properties of complexes 1 and 2. The crystal structures of complexes Mn(Hssal)(bipy)2(H2O)⋅2H2O (7)  and Zn(Hssal)(bipy)(H2O)2 (8)  were reported previously. The results demonstrate that the discrete or polymeric complexes may build up higher network connectivity through π-π stacking, C-H⋯π, O⋯π and hydrogen-bonding interactions including weak C-H⋯O contacts.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and physical measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin–Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. IR spectra were measured on a Perkin–Elmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Magnetic measurements were obtained using an MPMS-XL magnetometer at H<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Oe in the temperature range 5–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. The magnetic susceptibility data were corrected for the diamagnetism of the constituent atoms using Pascal’s constants.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and physical measurements

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. IR spectra were measured on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Magnetic measurements were obtained using an MPMS-XL magnetometer at H=1000Oe in the temperature range 5-300K. The magnetic susceptibility data were corrected for the diamagnetism of the constituent atoms using Pascal's constants.

elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of the complexes

Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(phen)4 ⋅7H2O (1)

A mixture of CuSO4 ⋅5H2O (0.131g, 0.5mmol), 5-sulfosalicylic acid (0.130g, 0.5mmol), phen (0.103g, 0.5mmol), KOH (0.062g, 1.1mmol) and water (15ml) was stirred for 30min at room temperature, transferred to and sealed in a 25ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, and then heated at 150°C for 72h. Upon cooling to room temperature, the dark green crystals that were obtained were filtered and washed with water. Yield: 58% based on Cu. Anal. Calc. for C62H56N8O21Cu4S2 1: C, 47.47; H, 3.57; N, 7.15; S, 4.08. Found: C, 47.52; H, 3.48; N, 7.13; S, 4.12%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3407vs, 1603s, 1563m, 1522w, 1472m, 1414m, 1320m, 1221m, 1167m, 1131s, 1146s, 1020s, 849s, 722vs, 604m, 479w.

The reflection data were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD area-detector diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, graphite monochromator) at room temperature with the <ce:italic>ω</ce:italic>-scan mode. Empirical adsorption corrections were applied to all data using the <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps> program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using <ce:small-caps>shelxtl</ce:small-caps>97 software . Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located from difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. All calculations were carried out using <ce:small-caps>shelxtl</ce:small-caps>97  and <ce:small-caps>platon</ce:small-caps>99 . The crystallographic data and pertinent information are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>, and any additional refinement information is given below.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray diffraction data and crystal structure determination

The crystal structures were determined by a single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiment. The reflection data were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD area-detector diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, graphite monochromator) at room temperature with the ω-scan mode. Empirical adsorption corrections were applied to all data using the sadabs program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares on F 2 using shelxtl97 software . Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located from difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors in complexes 1-6. All calculations were carried out using shelxtl97  and platon99 . The crystallographic data and pertinent information are summarized in  , and any additional refinement information is given below.

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, CuSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) in a molar ratio of 1:1:1 at different pH levels ranging from 5 to10 in an attempt to investigate the reactivity. The reactions were carried out in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. We obtained compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>8</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig17"></ce:float-anchor>) at different pH values. Coordination complexes of Cr(III), Cu(II) and Cd(II) were obtained under weakly acidic, neutral and weakly basic conditions, respectively. Complexes <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> were easily obtained for the wider pH range 5–8. It is worth noting that complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> were all directly obtained through the hydrothermal method, however, complexes <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> were synthesized through evaporation of the filtrate after the hydrothermal reaction. We tried to synthesize complexes <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> at room temperature, but failed. This demonstrates that complexes <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions.</ce:para>

Complex 2 Hydrogen atoms of O1w were not located from difference Fourier maps.

Complex 5 O2 and O3 atoms of the sulfonate group both showed disorder over two positions and were refined at 0.50 and 0.50 occupancy, and 0.41 and 0.59 occupancy, respectively.

Selected bond lengths and angles for complexes 1-6 are summarized in  . Geometrical parameters of the hydrogen bonds in complexes 1-6 are summarized in  .

Results and discussion

Synthesis

5-Sulfosalicylic acid and bipyridyl-like mixed ligands were reacted in aqueous medium with different metal salts (Cr2(SO4)3 ⋅6H2O, MnCl2 ⋅4H2O, CuSO4 ⋅5H2O, ZnCl2, 3CdSO4 ⋅8H2O) in a molar ratio of 1:1:1 at different pH levels ranging from 5 to10 in an attempt to investigate the reactivity. The reactions were carried out in a 25ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor at 150°C for 72h. We obtained compounds 1-8 ( ) at different pH values. Coordination complexes of Cr(III), Cu(II) and Cd(II) were obtained under weakly acidic, neutral and weakly basic conditions, respectively. Complexes 7 and 8 were easily obtained for the wider pH range 5-8. It is worth noting that complexes 1, 2, 3 and 5 were all directly obtained through the hydrothermal method, however, complexes 4, 6, 7 and 8 were synthesized through evaporation of the filtrate after the hydrothermal reaction. We tried to synthesize complexes 4, 6, 7 and 8 at room temperature, but failed. This demonstrates that complexes 4, 6, 7 and 8 were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Crystal structures of the complexes</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Structure description of Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ssal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">X-ray single crystal diffraction reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possesses a centrosymmetric Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> core based on a stepped topology (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>) . The Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> core is composed of two crystallographically independent Cu (II) atoms [namely, Cu1 and Cu2]. Cu1 and Cu2 both possess the configuration of a distorted square pyramid, however, there are two sets of coordination environments around the copper atoms. Cu1 is located in a plane consisting of two nitrogen atoms (N3 and N4) from a chelating phen molecule and two hydroxides (O7 and O7#1), and the axial position is occupied by the phenolato oxygen atom (O3). For Cu2, the plane is composed of two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from the phen molecule, one carboxylate oxygen (O1) and one phenolato oxygen atom (O3), and the corresponding axial position is taken by one hydroxide ion (O7#1). Cu1 and Cu2 atoms, with two symmetry-related copper centres, are connected into a Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> core by two μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-hydroxo groups and two phenolato oxygen atoms. The Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> core consists of a stepped structure in which three Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> planes are formed by Cu2 Cu1 O3 O7#1 I, Cu1 Cu1#1 O7 O7#1 II and Cu2#1 Cu1#1 O3#1 O7 III. Planes I and III, with a maximum deviation of 0.1308<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å from their least-squares planes, are parallel to each other, but both have the same bihedral angle of 103° with plane II. In the Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> core, we observed that the four Cu atoms form a flat rhomboid with sides Cu1⋯Cu2 and Cu1#1⋯Cu2 of lengths 3.18 and 3.59<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, a short diagonal (Cu1⋯Cu1#1) of 2.94<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and a long diagonal (Cu2⋯Cu2#1) of 6.10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Offset π–π interactions between phen molecules with a face-to-face distance of 3.43<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and offset angle of 28.74° stabilize the tetranuclear complex. To the best of our knowledge, only one copper complex constructed from mixed organic ligands with a stepped topology has previously been reported .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structures of the complexes

Structure description of Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(phen)4 ⋅7H2O (1)

X-ray single crystal diffraction reveals that compound 1 possesses a centrosymmetric Cu4O4 core based on a stepped topology ( ) . The Cu4O4 core is composed of two crystallographically independent Cu (II) atoms [namely, Cu1 and Cu2]. Cu1 and Cu2 both possess the configuration of a distorted square pyramid, however, there are two sets of coordination environments around the copper atoms. Cu1 is located in a plane consisting of two nitrogen atoms (N3 and N4) from a chelating phen molecule and two hydroxides (O7 and O7#1), and the axial position is occupied by the phenolato oxygen atom (O3). For Cu2, the plane is composed of two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from the phen molecule, one carboxylate oxygen (O1) and one phenolato oxygen atom (O3), and the corresponding axial position is taken by one hydroxide ion (O7#1). Cu1 and Cu2 atoms, with two symmetry-related copper centres, are connected into a Cu4O4 core by two μ3-hydroxo groups and two phenolato oxygen atoms. The Cu4O4 core consists of a stepped structure in which three Cu2O2 planes are formed by Cu2 Cu1 O3 O7#1 I, Cu1 Cu1#1 O7 O7#1 II and Cu2#1 Cu1#1 O3#1 O7 III. Planes I and III, with a maximum deviation of 0.1308Å from their least-squares planes, are parallel to each other, but both have the same bihedral angle of 103° with plane II. In the Cu4O4 core, we observed that the four Cu atoms form a flat rhomboid with sides Cu1⋯Cu2 and Cu1#1⋯Cu2 of lengths 3.18 and 3.59Å, respectively, a short diagonal (Cu1⋯Cu1#1) of 2.94Å and a long diagonal (Cu2⋯Cu2#1) of 6.10Å. Offset π-π interactions between phen molecules with a face-to-face distance of 3.43Å and offset angle of 28.74° stabilize the tetranuclear complex. To the best of our knowledge, only one copper complex constructed from mixed organic ligands with a stepped topology has previously been reported .

<ce:section-title>Structure description of Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ssal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have the same space group, <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. The molecular structures of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> show some similarities as follows: (a) Both possess the centrosymmetric Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> () core based on a stepped topology. (b) The central copper atoms in both complexes have the same coordination geometry, and the bond lengths and angles, as shown in , are also similar. (c) Both possess similar 2D supramolecular layers based on tetranuclear Cu (II) units. However, the replacement of phen by bipy, a chelating aromatic ligand of a smaller size, leads to some subtle differences. One difference worth noticing between the crystal structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> concerns the numbers of water molecules in their asymmetric units: 3.5 water molecules for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and one water molecule for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. This results in the formation of a 3D supramolecular network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>) for compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> differing from that of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. In compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the 2D layers are connected into a 3D supramolecular network through O1w with symmetry-related layers and π–π interactions between adjacent Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ssal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> units (offset π–π interactions between 2,2′-bipy molecules with a face-to-face distance of 3.54<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and offset angle of 24.71°).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure description of Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(bipy)4 ⋅2H2O (2)

Complexes 1 and 2 have the same space group, P21/c. The molecular structures of complexes 1 and 2 show some similarities as follows: (a) Both possess the centrosymmetric Cu4O4 () core based on a stepped topology. (b) The central copper atoms in both complexes have the same coordination geometry, and the bond lengths and angles, as shown in , are also similar. (c) Both possess similar 2D supramolecular layers based on tetranuclear Cu (II) units. However, the replacement of phen by bipy, a chelating aromatic ligand of a smaller size, leads to some subtle differences. One difference worth noticing between the crystal structures of 1 and 2 concerns the numbers of water molecules in their asymmetric units: 3.5 water molecules for 1 and one water molecule for 2. This results in the formation of a 3D supramolecular network ( ) for compound 2 differing from that of compound 1. In compound 2, the 2D layers are connected into a 3D supramolecular network through O1w with symmetry-related layers and π-π interactions between adjacent Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(bipy)4 units (offset π-π interactions between 2,2'-bipy molecules with a face-to-face distance of 3.54Å and offset angle of 24.71°).

These dimeric Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units, featuring a 1D ladder (

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-chelating and μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>

Structure description of Cd(Hssal)(bipy) (3)

The crystal analysis of complex 3 reveals that it is a one-dimensional ladder coordination polymer containing Cd2O8 (2,2'-bipy)2 units ( a) with Hssal as the bridge ligands. The asymmetric unit of complex 3 consists of one Cd atom, one Hssal anion and one 2,2'-bipy ligand. The Cd center adopts a distorted capped-octahedral conformation (b) in which the basal plane is formed by two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from a chelating 2,2'-bipy ligand, a carboxylate oxygen atom (O2) and a sulfonate oxygen atom (O6) from two different Hssal anions. The axial positions are taken by a carboxylate oxygen atom (O1) and a sulfonate oxygen atom (O6#3). The sulfonate oxygen atom (O4) occupies the capped position. Each pair of Cd ions is bridged by a sulfonate oxygen atom (O6) with symmetry-related partner (O6#3) to form a Cd2O8 (2,2'-bipy)2 unit. These dimeric Cd2 units, featuring a 1D ladder ( a) along the crystallographica axis, are interconnected by Hssal2- anions. Each Hssal2- anion connects three Cd (II) atoms (b) with the carboxylic group and sulfonate group, adopting μ1 -η1:η1-chelating and μ2 -η0:η1:η2-bridging/chelating coordination modes . As far as we know, this kind of new coordination mode of the Hssal2- group has not been reported previously. The adjacent chains are further aggregated into a 2D sheet () through π-π interactions between phen ligands, with a face-to-face distance of 3.47Å and offset angle 36.52°, chelating C-H⋯O hydrogen bonding (C4⋯O5=3.39, C7⋯O5=3.41Å) and C-H⋯π interactions between C8 and H5 from 2,2'-bipy ligands and Hssal2- rings containing C16 (, H5⋯π=2.72 and C8⋯π=3.59Å).

The axial positions are occupied by a nitrogen atom (N1#4) from a phen molecule and a sulfonate oxygen atom (O1). The π–π interactions between the aromatic rings of the different ligands are favorable to stabilize complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. The closest centroid separation is 3.76<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å from the <ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-hydroxybenzenesulfonic ligand to the C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> ring of the phen ligand, with an offset angle of 19.85°. Interestingly, the Cd(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> molecules are connected into 1D supramolecular double chains (), sharing Cd(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units by O–H⋯O hydrogen bonding (O4⋯O3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.71<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) along the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis. The adjacent double chains are further aggregated into a 3D supramolecular network (

Structure description of Cd(HL)2(phen)2 (4)

The crystal analysis of complex 4 reveals that it is a mononuclear complex consisting of one Cd (II) ion, two phen molecules and two p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid anions. The Cd (II) center exhibits a distorted octahedral surrounding ( ), in which the basal plane is formed by three nitrogen atoms (N1, N1#4 and N2) from two symmetry-related phen molecules and one sulfonate oxygen atom (O1#4). The axial positions are occupied by a nitrogen atom (N1#4) from a phen molecule and a sulfonate oxygen atom (O1). The π-π interactions between the aromatic rings of the different ligands are favorable to stabilize complex 4. The closest centroid separation is 3.76Å from the p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic ligand to the C6 ring of the phen ligand, with an offset angle of 19.85°. Interestingly, the Cd(L)2(phen)2 molecules are connected into 1D supramolecular double chains (), sharing Cd(phen)2 units by O-H⋯O hydrogen bonding (O4⋯O3=2.71Å) along the crystallographic c-axis. The adjacent double chains are further aggregated into a 3D supramolecular network ( ) through π-π interactions between phen ligands (the closest centroid separation is 3.679Å between C6 rings with an offset angle of 16.31°) and C-H⋯O hydrogen bonding (C18⋯O2=3.20Å).

<ce:section-title>Structure description of Cr(ssal)(bipy) (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">X-ray single crystal diffraction reveals that the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> contains one Cr(III) ion, one ssal anion, one 2,2′-bipy molecule, two coordinated water and two lattice water molecules. The Cr(III) center exhibits a distorted octahedral surrounding (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor>), in which the basal plane is formed by two nitrogen atoms from a chelating 2,2′-bipy ligand (N1 and N2) and one carboxylate oxygen (O2) and one phenolic oxygen (O3) from a ssal ligand. The axial positions are occupied by O3w and O4w. Each Cr(ssal)(bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> unit is hydrogen bonded to two other units to form a 1D supramolecular helical chain () resulting from O–H⋯O hydrogen bonds involving O3w, O2w, O1, O1w and O4. Within the chain, the π–π interactions between the aromatic rings of the different ligands may stabilize the polymeric supramolecular chain. The closest centroid separation is 4.01<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å from the ssal<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand to the C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>N ring (containing the N2 atom) of the 2,2′-bipy ligand with an offset angle of 26.09°. The 1D chains are further linked into a 2D layer (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig10"></ce:float-anchor>) through O–H⋯O hydrogen bonding (O2w⋯O5, O1w⋯O4w), the geometrical parameters of the hydrogen bonds of compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are collected in . The most remarkable feature of this 2D layer is that there exist a supramolecular ring () consisting of four coordinated water molecules (O3w and O4w), six lattice water molecules (O1w and O2w), three ssal<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> anions and three Cr<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions, formed through covalent bonds and hydrogen bonds. Only the 2,2′-bipy molecules occupy the supramolecular rings, preventing interpenetration. Finally, the 2D layers are hydrogen bonded through O4wB-H4wB⋯O6 to afford a 3D supramolecular network (). Compared with some active transition metals (Zn, Cd, Cu, etc.), coordination complexes of Cr are relatively fewer due to its inertness (slow polymerization and difficulty of substitution) . To the best of our knowledge, complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> is the first example of a chromium 5-sulfosalicylate complex.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure description of Cr(ssal)(bipy) (H2O)2 ⋅2H2O (5)

X-ray single crystal diffraction reveals that the asymmetric unit of 5 contains one Cr(III) ion, one ssal anion, one 2,2'-bipy molecule, two coordinated water and two lattice water molecules. The Cr(III) center exhibits a distorted octahedral surrounding ( ), in which the basal plane is formed by two nitrogen atoms from a chelating 2,2'-bipy ligand (N1 and N2) and one carboxylate oxygen (O2) and one phenolic oxygen (O3) from a ssal ligand. The axial positions are occupied by O3w and O4w. Each Cr(ssal)(bipy)2(H2O)2 unit is hydrogen bonded to two other units to form a 1D supramolecular helical chain () resulting from O-H⋯O hydrogen bonds involving O3w, O2w, O1, O1w and O4. Within the chain, the π-π interactions between the aromatic rings of the different ligands may stabilize the polymeric supramolecular chain. The closest centroid separation is 4.01Å from the ssal3- ligand to the C5N ring (containing the N2 atom) of the 2,2'-bipy ligand with an offset angle of 26.09°. The 1D chains are further linked into a 2D layer ( ) through O-H⋯O hydrogen bonding (O2w⋯O5, O1w⋯O4w), the geometrical parameters of the hydrogen bonds of compound 5 are collected in . The most remarkable feature of this 2D layer is that there exist a supramolecular ring () consisting of four coordinated water molecules (O3w and O4w), six lattice water molecules (O1w and O2w), three ssal3- anions and three Cr3+ ions, formed through covalent bonds and hydrogen bonds. Only the 2,2'-bipy molecules occupy the supramolecular rings, preventing interpenetration. Finally, the 2D layers are hydrogen bonded through O4wB-H4wB⋯O6 to afford a 3D supramolecular network (). Compared with some active transition metals (Zn, Cd, Cu, etc.), coordination complexes of Cr are relatively fewer due to its inertness (slow polymerization and difficulty of substitution) . To the best of our knowledge, complex 5 is the first example of a chromium 5-sulfosalicylate complex.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Structure description of Cr(ssal)(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig11"></ce:float-anchor>) contains one Cr (III) ion, one ssal anion and two phen molecules. The Cr(III) center exhibits a distorted octahedral surrounding, in which the basal plane is formed by two nitrogen atoms from two different phen ligands (N2 and N4) and two bidentate chelating coordination oxygen atoms from one carboxylate oxygen (O1) and one phenolic oxygen (O3). The axial positions are occupied by N1 and N3 from two different phen ligands. Each Cr(ssal)(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> unit is hydrogen bonded to four other units to form a 2D puckered supramolecular layer () through C–H⋯O (C10–H8⋯O5, C22–H9⋯O4). Moreover, O⋯π (, the distance of O5 to the C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>N ring containing the N3 atom is 3.10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å)  and π⋯π interactions between the aromatic rings of different ligands (the closest centroid separation is 3.91<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å from the aryl of the ssal anion ligand to the C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> ring of the phen ligand with an offset angle of 23.91°) stabilize the 2D puckered supramolecular layer. The 2D layers are held together into a 2D supramolecular double-layer through π⋯π interactions between phen ligands (the closest centroid separation is 3.79<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å between the C6 rings of phen ligands with an offset angle of 25.79°). The 2D double layers are further aggregated into a 3D supramolecular network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig12"></ce:float-anchor>) through infinite π-stacking between the phen ligands in head-to-tail way (the closest centroid separation is 3.86<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with an offset angle of 13.27°).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure description of Cr(ssal)(phen)2 (6)

The asymmetric unit of 6 ( ) contains one Cr (III) ion, one ssal anion and two phen molecules. The Cr(III) center exhibits a distorted octahedral surrounding, in which the basal plane is formed by two nitrogen atoms from two different phen ligands (N2 and N4) and two bidentate chelating coordination oxygen atoms from one carboxylate oxygen (O1) and one phenolic oxygen (O3). The axial positions are occupied by N1 and N3 from two different phen ligands. Each Cr(ssal)(phen)2 unit is hydrogen bonded to four other units to form a 2D puckered supramolecular layer () through C-H⋯O (C10-H8⋯O5, C22-H9⋯O4). Moreover, O⋯π (, the distance of O5 to the C5N ring containing the N3 atom is 3.10Å)  and π⋯π interactions between the aromatic rings of different ligands (the closest centroid separation is 3.91Å from the aryl of the ssal anion ligand to the C6 ring of the phen ligand with an offset angle of 23.91°) stabilize the 2D puckered supramolecular layer. The 2D layers are held together into a 2D supramolecular double-layer through π⋯π interactions between phen ligands (the closest centroid separation is 3.79Å between the C6 rings of phen ligands with an offset angle of 25.79°). The 2D double layers are further aggregated into a 3D supramolecular network ( ) through infinite π-stacking between the phen ligands in head-to-tail way (the closest centroid separation is 3.86Å with an offset angle of 13.27°).

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic studies of complexes 1-2 

The variable temperature magnetic susceptibility of complexes 1 and 2 was measured at 1000G in the temperature range 5-300K. The magnetic behaviors of 1 are depicted in   in the forms of χ M and μeff versus T plots (χ M being the molar magnetic susceptibility). As the temperature is lowered, χ M increases slowly until about 50K, then it dramatically increases at lower temperatures. The data between 300 and 5K can be fit to the Curie-Weiss expression, χ M = C/(T - θ), [C =0.125 g 2∑S(S +1)], with the Curie constant C =1.71cm3 Kmol-1, Weiss constant θ =7.5K and g =2.14. On the other hand, at room temperature the effective magnetic moment (μ eff) equals 3.701 μ B, which is slightly higher than the spin-only value of four uncoupled copper (II) S =1/2 ions (theoretical value for g= 2, μ eff =3.464 μ B). The μ eff value increases gradually until 5K, reaching a value of 4.037 μ B. This feature is characteristic of the presence of significant ferromagnetic interactions between the copper (II) ions . Moreover, the positive sign of the Weiss constant also indicates there exist ferromagnetic interactions between the Cu (II) centers.

elements.clean_text: The magnetic behavior of complex 2 is shown in   in the forms of χ M and μ eff versus T plots. As the temperature is lowered, χ M increases slowly until about 38K, then it dramatically increases at lower temperatures. The data between 300 and 38K can be fit to the Curie-Weiss expression, χ M = C/(T - θ), [C =0.125 g 2 S(S +1)], with the Curie constant C =0.784cm3 mol-1 K and Weiss constant θ =-0.401K. The effective magnetic moment (μ eff) in 2 decreases slowly from 3.43 μ B at 300K to 3.21 μ B at 55K, and then falls rapidly, reaching 2.46 μ B at 5K. At room temperature the effective magnetic moment (μ eff) equals 3.43 μ B, which is slightly lower than the spin-only value of four uncoupled copper (II) S =1/2 ions (theoretical value for g =2, μ eff =3.46 μ B). These features indicate that there exist anti-ferromagnetic interactions amongst the Cu (II) centers . The difference in the magnetic properties of complexes 1 and 2 is possibly the result of the different intermolecular contacts.

In order to understand the nature of the emission bands of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, we also investigated the luminescence of the free 2, 2-bipy, phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>ssal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O ligands in the solid state at room temperature. The emission bands for free phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O are at 365, 381, 403 and 437<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">exc.</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>344<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), which may be attributed to the π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π transition (). <ce:inf loc="post">exc.</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>352<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), are also attributed to the π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π transition (). However, the emission bands for free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>ssal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O are mainly located at about 387<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm with a shoulder peak at 440<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>ssal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O: <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> transitions (). Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibits intense green photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 520<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 347<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (). Compared with the emission spectra of the free 2, 2-bipy and H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>ssal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O ligands, the band at 520<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> might be assigned to the emission of a ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), similar to reported Cd complexes . Complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> displays intense blue photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 440<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 329<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (), compared with the emission spectra of the free phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>ssal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O ligands, the band at 440<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is neither LMCT (ligand-to-metal charge transfer) nor MLCT (metal-to-ligand charge transfer) in nature, and tentatively might be assigned to an intraligand fluorescent emission .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent properties of complexes 3-4 

The solid-state fluorescent spectra of complexes 3 and 4 are depicted in   , respectively. In order to understand the nature of the emission bands of complex 3 and 4, we also investigated the luminescence of the free 2, 2-bipy, phen⋅H2O and H3ssal⋅2H2O ligands in the solid state at room temperature. The emission bands for free phen⋅H2O are at 365, 381, 403 and 437nm (λ exc. =344nm), which may be attributed to the π∗ →π transition (). Similar to free phen⋅H2O, the emission bands for the free 2, 2-bipy ligand, at 390, 413 and 438nm (λ exc. =352nm), are also attributed to the π∗ →π transition (). However, the emission bands for free H3ssal⋅2H2O are mainly located at about 387nm with a shoulder peak at 440nm (H3ssal⋅2H2O: λ exc. =335nm) and are attributed to π∗ → n transitions (). Complex 3 exhibits intense green photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 520nm upon excitation at 347nm (). Compared with the emission spectra of the free 2, 2-bipy and H3ssal⋅2H2O ligands, the band at 520nm for 3 might be assigned to the emission of a ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), similar to reported Cd complexes . Complex 4 displays intense blue photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 440nm upon excitation at 329nm (), compared with the emission spectra of the free phen⋅H2O and H3ssal⋅2H2O ligands, the band at 440nm for 4 is neither LMCT (ligand-to-metal charge transfer) nor MLCT (metal-to-ligand charge transfer) in nature, and tentatively might be assigned to an intraligand fluorescent emission .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Six new complexes constructed from 5-sulfosalicylic acid and bipyridyl-like ligands (2,2′-bipy and 1,10-phen), namely [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ssal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ssal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [Cd(Hssal)(bipy)] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), [Cd(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), [Cr(ssal)(bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) and [Cr(ssal)(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>), (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>ssal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-sulfosalicylic acid, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid, bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′-bipy, phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,10-phen) were prepared under hydrothermal conditions and their structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are both tetranuclear copper complexes with a stepped topology. In complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, a new coordination mode of the Hssal<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> group is reported in this work. During the synthetic process of complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> decarboxylation of 5-sulfosalicylic acid into <ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid is involved. Two chromium 5-sulfosalicylates (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) are reported for the first time. These new complexes display different supramolecular structures by O–H⋯O, C–H⋯O hydrogen bonds as well as π⋯π, C–H⋯π and O⋯π interactions (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig18"></ce:float-anchor>). Of the six complexes described in this work, the π-stacking interactions (O⋯π, C–H⋯π and π⋯π) play an important role in the observed structural stability. It is likely that studies on similar systems would be favorable for understanding the nature of the π-stacking and its role in structural stability.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Six new complexes constructed from 5-sulfosalicylic acid and bipyridyl-like ligands (2,2'-bipy and 1,10-phen), namely [Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(phen)4 ⋅7H2O] (1), [Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(bipy)4 ⋅2H2O] (2), [Cd(Hssal)(bipy)] (3), [Cd(HL)2(phen)2] (4), [Cr(ssal)(bipy)(H2O)2 ⋅2H2O] (5) and [Cr(ssal)(phen)2] (6), (H3ssal=5-sulfosalicylic acid, H2L= p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid, bipy=2,2'-bipy, phen=1,10-phen) were prepared under hydrothermal conditions and their structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complexes 1 and 2 are both tetranuclear copper complexes with a stepped topology. In complex 3, a new coordination mode of the Hssal2- group is reported in this work. During the synthetic process of complex 4, in situ decarboxylation of 5-sulfosalicylic acid into p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid is involved. Two chromium 5-sulfosalicylates (5 and 6) are reported for the first time. These new complexes display different supramolecular structures by O-H⋯O, C-H⋯O hydrogen bonds as well as π⋯π, C-H⋯π and O⋯π interactions ( ). Of the six complexes described in this work, the π-stacking interactions (O⋯π, C-H⋯π and π⋯π) play an important role in the observed structural stability. It is likely that studies on similar systems would be favorable for understanding the nature of the π-stacking and its role in structural stability.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Syntheses of the complexes</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ssal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A mixture of CuSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.131<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 5-sulfosalicylic acid (0.130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), phen (0.103<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), KOH (0.062<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and water (15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) was stirred for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min at room temperature, transferred to and sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, and then heated at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Upon cooling to room temperature, the dark green crystals that were obtained were filtered and washed with water. Yield: 58% based on Cu. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">62</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">56</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">21</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: C, 47.47; H, 3.57; N, 7.15; S, 4.08. Found: C, 47.52; H, 3.48; N, 7.13; S, 4.12%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3407vs, 1603s, 1563m, 1522w, 1472m, 1414m, 1320m, 1221m, 1167m, 1131s, 1146s, 1020s, 849s, 722vs, 604m, 479w.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ssal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The hydrothermal procedure for the synthesis of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is similar to that for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> except for the replacement of phen with 2,2-bipy (0.082<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol). Yield: 82% based on Cu. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">54</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">44</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: C, 46.98; H, 3.19; N, 8.12; S, 4.64. Found: C, 46.85; H, 3.02; N, 8.09; S, 4.58%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3444m, 1602s, 1562m, 1470m, 1413w, 1341w, 1253w, 1211m, 1186m, 1150m, 1030s 771m, 604m, 470w.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Cd(Hssal)(bipy) (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A mixture of 3CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.403<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 5-sulfosalicylic acid (0.132<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 2,2′-bipy (0.081<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), KOH (0.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and water (15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) was stirred for 30 min at room temperature, transferred to and sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, and then heated at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Upon cooling to room temperature, the light red crystals that were obtained were filtered and washed with water. Yield: 58% based on Cd. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>CdS <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>: C, 42.08; H, 2.48; N, 4.95; S, 6.60. Found: C, 41.94; H, 2.52; N, 4.87; S, 6.63%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3112m, 1626w, 1596m, 1559m, 1478m, 1440m, 1254m, 1158m, 1127s, 1017s, 769m, 676m, 602m.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Cd(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A mixture of 3CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.407<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 5-sulfosalicylic acid (0.132<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), phen (0.108<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), KOH (0.071<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and water (15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) was stirred for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min at room temperature, transferred to and sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, and then heated at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Upon cooling to room temperature, a colorless solution and a spot of white precipitate were obtained. The solution was filtered and the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature. After slow evaporation over several days, red block single crystals were obtained. Yield: 62% based on Cd. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>CdS<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>: C, 52.74; H, 3.17; N, 6.84; S, 7.81. Found: C, 52.67; H, 3.23; N, 6.79; S, 7.83%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3168m, 1586m, 1506m, 1424m, 1237s, 1156s, 1122s, 1031s, 844s, 728s, 566m, 451w.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Cr(ssal)(bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A mixture of Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.255<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 5-sulfosalicylic acid (0.134<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 2,2′-bipy (0.082<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), KOH (0.051<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and water (15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) was stirred for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min at room temperature, transferred to and sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, and then heated at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Upon cooling to room temperature, the green crystals that were obtained were filtered and washed with water. Yield: 5% based on Cr. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>CrS <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>: C, 41.18; H, 3.84; N, 5.65; S, 6.46. Found: C, 41.11; H, 3.90; N, 5.57%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3446s, 1608s, 1571m, 1447m, 1472m, 1150s, 1031s, 763m, 602m.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Cr(ssal)(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A mixture of Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.253<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 5-sulfosalicylic acid (0.136<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), phen (0.106<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), KOH (0.062<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and water (15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) was stirred for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min at room temperature, transferred to and sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, and then heated at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Upon cooling to room temperature, a red solution was obtained, which was filtered and the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature. Found: C, 44.12; H, 3.66; N, 5.97; S, 6.68%. <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, MnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, CuSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, 3CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) in a molar ratio of 1:1:1 at different pH levels ranging from 5 to10 in an attempt to investigate the reactivity. The reactions were carried out in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. We obtained compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>8</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig17"></ce:float-anchor>) at different pH values. Coordination complexes of Cr(III), Cu(II) and Cd(II) were obtained under weakly acidic, neutral and weakly basic conditions, respectively. Complexes <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> were easily obtained for the wider pH range 5–8. It is worth noting that complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> were all directly obtained through the hydrothermal method, however, complexes <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> were synthesized through evaporation of the filtrate after the hydrothermal reaction. We tried to synthesize complexes <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> at room temperature, but failed. This demonstrates that complexes <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions.</ce:para>

Syntheses of the complexes

Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(phen)4 ⋅7H2O (1)

A mixture of CuSO4 ⋅5H2O (0.131g, 0.5mmol), 5-sulfosalicylic acid (0.130g, 0.5mmol), phen (0.103g, 0.5mmol), KOH (0.062g, 1.1mmol) and water (15ml) was stirred for 30min at room temperature, transferred to and sealed in a 25ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, and then heated at 150°C for 72h. Upon cooling to room temperature, the dark green crystals that were obtained were filtered and washed with water. Yield: 58% based on Cu. Anal. Calc. for C62H56N8O21Cu4S2 1: C, 47.47; H, 3.57; N, 7.15; S, 4.08. Found: C, 47.52; H, 3.48; N, 7.13; S, 4.12%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3407vs, 1603s, 1563m, 1522w, 1472m, 1414m, 1320m, 1221m, 1167m, 1131s, 1146s, 1020s, 849s, 722vs, 604m, 479w.

Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(bipy)4 ⋅2H2O (2)

The hydrothermal procedure for the synthesis of complex 2 is similar to that for 1 except for the replacement of phen with 2,2-bipy (0.082g, 0.5mmol). Yield: 82% based on Cu. Anal. Calc. for C54H44N8O16Cu4S2 2: C, 46.98; H, 3.19; N, 8.12; S, 4.64. Found: C, 46.85; H, 3.02; N, 8.09; S, 4.58%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3444m, 1602s, 1562m, 1470m, 1413w, 1341w, 1253w, 1211m, 1186m, 1150m, 1030s 771m, 604m, 470w.

Cd(Hssal)(bipy) (3)

A mixture of 3CdSO4 ⋅8H2O (0.403g, 0.5mmol), 5-sulfosalicylic acid (0.132g, 0.5mmol), 2,2'-bipy (0.081g, 0.5mmol), KOH (0.08g, 1.4mmol) and water (15ml) was stirred for 30 min at room temperature, transferred to and sealed in a 25ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, and then heated at 150°C for 72h. Upon cooling to room temperature, the light red crystals that were obtained were filtered and washed with water. Yield: 58% based on Cd. Anal. Calc. for C17H12N2O6CdS 3: C, 42.08; H, 2.48; N, 4.95; S, 6.60. Found: C, 41.94; H, 2.52; N, 4.87; S, 6.63%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3112m, 1626w, 1596m, 1559m, 1478m, 1440m, 1254m, 1158m, 1127s, 1017s, 769m, 676m, 602m.

Cd(HL)2(phen)2 (4)

A mixture of 3CdSO4 ⋅8H2O (0.407g, 0.5mmol), 5-sulfosalicylic acid (0.132g, 0.5mmol), phen (0.108g, 0.5mmol), KOH (0.071g, 1.3mmol) and water (15ml) was stirred for 30min at room temperature, transferred to and sealed in a 25ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, and then heated at 150°C for 72h. Upon cooling to room temperature, a colorless solution and a spot of white precipitate were obtained. The solution was filtered and the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature. After slow evaporation over several days, red block single crystals were obtained. Yield: 62% based on Cd. Anal. Calc. for C36H26N4O8CdS2 4: C, 52.74; H, 3.17; N, 6.84; S, 7.81. Found: C, 52.67; H, 3.23; N, 6.79; S, 7.83%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3168m, 1586m, 1506m, 1424m, 1237s, 1156s, 1122s, 1031s, 844s, 728s, 566m, 451w.

Cr(ssal)(bipy)2(H2O)2 ⋅2H2O (5)

A mixture of Cr2(SO4)3 ⋅6H2O (0.255g, 0.5mmol), 5-sulfosalicylic acid (0.134g, 0.5mmol), 2,2'-bipy (0.082g, 0.5mmol), KOH (0.051g, 0.9mmol) and water (15ml) was stirred for 30min at room temperature, transferred to and sealed in a 25ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, and then heated at 150°C for 72h. Upon cooling to room temperature, the green crystals that were obtained were filtered and washed with water. Yield: 5% based on Cr. Anal. Calc. for C17H19N2O10CrS 5: C, 41.18; H, 3.84; N, 5.65; S, 6.46. Found: C, 41.11; H, 3.90; N, 5.57%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3446s, 1608s, 1571m, 1447m, 1472m, 1150s, 1031s, 763m, 602m.

Cr(ssal)(phen)2 (6)

A mixture of Cr2(SO4)3 ⋅6H2O (0.253g, 0.5mmol), 5-sulfosalicylic acid (0.136g, 0.5mmol), phen (0.106g, 0.5mmol), KOH (0.062g, 1.1mmol) and water (15ml) was stirred for 30min at room temperature, transferred to and sealed in a 25ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, and then heated at 150°C for 72h. Upon cooling to room temperature, a red solution was obtained, which was filtered and the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature. After slow evaporation over several days, red block single crystals were obtained. Yield: 35% based on Cr. Anal. Calc. for C31H19N4O6CrS 6: C, 59.28; H, 3.03; N, 8.92; S, 5.10. Found: C, 59.35; H, 2.84; N, 8.97; S, 5.18%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3078vw, 1608s, 1574m, 1517m, 1469s, 1426s, 1311m, 1167s, 1033s, 845m, 721m, 601m, 451m.

Mn(Hssal)(bipy)2(H2O)⋅2H2O (7)

The hydrothermal procedure for the synthesis of complex 7 is similar to that for 6 except for the replacement of Cr2(SO4)3 ⋅6H2O with MnCl2 ⋅4H2O (0.108g, 0.5mmol). The yellow solution was obtained, filtered, and the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature. After slow evaporation over several days, yellow block single crystals were obtained. Yield: 65% based on Mn. Anal. Calc. for C27H26N4O9MnS 7: C, 50.82; H, 4.08; N, 8.78; S, 5.02. Found: C, 50.65; H, 3.96; N, 8.97; S, 5.18%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3453s, 1592s, 1517m, 1469s, 1426m, 1311m, 1167vs, 1033s, 845m, 721s, 601m, 451m.

Zn(Hssal)(bipy)(H2O)2 (8)

The hydrothermal procedure for the synthesis of complex 8 is similar to that for 6 except for the replacement of Cr2(SO4)3 ⋅6H2O with ZnCl2 (0.074g, 0.5mmol). A colorless solution and a spot of white deposition were obtained. The solution was filtered and the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature. After slow evaporation over several days, colorless block single crystals were obtained. Yield: 72% based on Zn. Anal. Calc. for C17H16N2O8SZn 8: C, 43.06; H, 3.38; N, 5.91; S, 6.75. Found: C, 44.12; H, 3.66; N, 5.97; S, 6.68%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3283s, 1584s, 1441s, 1153vs, 1053s, 672s, 567s.

Complex 2 Hydrogen atoms of O1w were not located from difference Fourier maps.

Complex 5 O2 and O3 atoms of the sulfonate group both showed disorder over two positions and were refined at 0.50 and 0.50 occupancy, and 0.41 and 0.59 occupancy, respectively.

Selected bond lengths and angles for complexes 1-6 are summarized in  . Geometrical parameters of the hydrogen bonds in complexes 1-6 are summarized in  .

Results and discussion

Synthesis

5-Sulfosalicylic acid and bipyridyl-like mixed ligands were reacted in aqueous medium with different metal salts (Cr2(SO4)3 ⋅6H2O, MnCl2 ⋅4H2O, CuSO4 ⋅5H2O, ZnCl2, 3CdSO4 ⋅8H2O) in a molar ratio of 1:1:1 at different pH levels ranging from 5 to10 in an attempt to investigate the reactivity. The reactions were carried out in a 25ml Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor at 150°C for 72h. We obtained compounds 1-8 ( ) at different pH values. Coordination complexes of Cr(III), Cu(II) and Cd(II) were obtained under weakly acidic, neutral and weakly basic conditions, respectively. Complexes 7 and 8 were easily obtained for the wider pH range 5-8. It is worth noting that complexes 1, 2, 3 and 5 were all directly obtained through the hydrothermal method, however, complexes 4, 6, 7 and 8 were synthesized through evaporation of the filtrate after the hydrothermal reaction. We tried to synthesize complexes 4, 6, 7 and 8 at room temperature, but failed. This demonstrates that complexes 4, 6, 7 and 8 were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions.

<ce:section-title>Crystal structures of the complexes</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Structure description of Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ssal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">X-ray single crystal diffraction reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possesses a centrosymmetric Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> core based on a stepped topology (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>) . The Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> core is composed of two crystallographically independent Cu (II) atoms [namely, Cu1 and Cu2]. Cu1 and Cu2 both possess the configuration of a distorted square pyramid, however, there are two sets of coordination environments around the copper atoms. Cu1 is located in a plane consisting of two nitrogen atoms (N3 and N4) from a chelating phen molecule and two hydroxides (O7 and O7#1), and the axial position is occupied by the phenolato oxygen atom (O3). For Cu2, the plane is composed of two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from the phen molecule, one carboxylate oxygen (O1) and one phenolato oxygen atom (O3), and the corresponding axial position is taken by one hydroxide ion (O7#1). Cu1 and Cu2 atoms, with two symmetry-related copper centres, are connected into a Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> core by two μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-hydroxo groups and two phenolato oxygen atoms. The Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> core consists of a stepped structure in which three Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> planes are formed by Cu2 Cu1 O3 O7#1 I, Cu1 Cu1#1 O7 O7#1 II and Cu2#1 Cu1#1 O3#1 O7 III. Planes I and III, with a maximum deviation of 0.1308<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å from their least-squares planes, are parallel to each other, but both have the same bihedral angle of 103° with plane II. In the Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> core, we observed that the four Cu atoms form a flat rhomboid with sides Cu1⋯Cu2 and Cu1#1⋯Cu2 of lengths 3.18 and 3.59<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, a short diagonal (Cu1⋯Cu1#1) of 2.94<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and a long diagonal (Cu2⋯Cu2#1) of 6.10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Offset π–π interactions between phen molecules with a face-to-face distance of 3.43<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and offset angle of 28.74° stabilize the tetranuclear complex. To the best of our knowledge, only one copper complex constructed from mixed organic ligands with a stepped topology has previously been reported .</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Each Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ssal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> molecule is linked to four neighboring tetrameric units to form a 2D supramolecular layer () of rhombic windows (with dimensions of 6.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>13.44<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) through hydrogen bonding between μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-hydroxo groups (O7) and the uncoordinated sulfonate oxygen atoms (O4). The 2D layers are connected into a 3D supramolecular network by water heptamers (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>), the geometrical parameters of the hydrogen bonds are given in . In addition to hydrogen bonding, inter-layer contacts are strengthened by intermolecular π–π interactions between adjacent Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ssal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> units (offset π–π interaction between phen molecules with a face-to-face distance of 3.47<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and offset angle 36.53°). Interestingly, the water heptamers and sulfonate anions are interconnected into a 2D supramolecular layer with very large rhombic windows (with dimensions of 12.57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>17.77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) through hydrogen bonding (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). The tetranuclear Cu (II) units are right inside the large rhombic windows between the 2D layers ).</ce:para><ce:section-title>Magnetic studies of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The variable temperature magnetic susceptibility of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was measured at 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>G in the temperature range 5–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. The magnetic behaviors of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig13"></ce:float-anchor> in the forms of <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> and μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> versus <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> plots (<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> being the molar magnetic susceptibility). As the temperature is lowered, <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> increases slowly until about 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, then it dramatically increases at lower temperatures. The data between 300 and 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K can be fit to the Curie–Weiss expression, <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>

<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf>) equals 3.701 <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>, which is slightly higher than the spin-only value of four uncoupled copper (II) <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2 ions (theoretical value for <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>= 2, <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.464 <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>). The <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> value increases gradually until 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, reaching a value of 4.037 <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>. This feature is characteristic of the presence of significant ferromagnetic interactions between the copper (II) ions . Moreover, the positive sign of the Weiss constant also indicates there exist ferromagnetic interactions between the Cu (II) centers.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The magnetic behavior of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is shown in

cln_elements.clean_text:
Crystal structures of the complexes

Structure description of Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(phen)4 ⋅7H2O (1)

X-ray single crystal diffraction reveals that compound 1 possesses a centrosymmetric Cu4O4 core based on a stepped topology ( ) . The Cu4O4 core is composed of two crystallographically independent Cu (II) atoms [namely, Cu1 and Cu2]. Cu1 and Cu2 both possess the configuration of a distorted square pyramid, however, there are two sets of coordination environments around the copper atoms. Cu1 is located in a plane consisting of two nitrogen atoms (N3 and N4) from a chelating phen molecule and two hydroxides (O7 and O7#1), and the axial position is occupied by the phenolato oxygen atom (O3). For Cu2, the plane is composed of two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from the phen molecule, one carboxylate oxygen (O1) and one phenolato oxygen atom (O3), and the corresponding axial position is taken by one hydroxide ion (O7#1). Cu1 and Cu2 atoms, with two symmetry-related copper centres, are connected into a Cu4O4 core by two μ3-hydroxo groups and two phenolato oxygen atoms. The Cu4O4 core consists of a stepped structure in which three Cu2O2 planes are formed by Cu2 Cu1 O3 O7#1 I, Cu1 Cu1#1 O7 O7#1 II and Cu2#1 Cu1#1 O3#1 O7 III. Planes I and III, with a maximum deviation of 0.1308Å from their least-squares planes, are parallel to each other, but both have the same bihedral angle of 103° with plane II. In the Cu4O4 core, we observed that the four Cu atoms form a flat rhomboid with sides Cu1⋯Cu2 and Cu1#1⋯Cu2 of lengths 3.18 and 3.59Å, respectively, a short diagonal (Cu1⋯Cu1#1) of 2.94Å and a long diagonal (Cu2⋯Cu2#1) of 6.10Å. Offset π-π interactions between phen molecules with a face-to-face distance of 3.43Å and offset angle of 28.74° stabilize the tetranuclear complex. To the best of our knowledge, only one copper complex constructed from mixed organic ligands with a stepped topology has previously been reported .

Each Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(phen)4 molecule is linked to four neighboring tetrameric units to form a 2D supramolecular layer () of rhombic windows (with dimensions of 6.05×13.44Å) through hydrogen bonding between μ3-hydroxo groups (O7) and the uncoordinated sulfonate oxygen atoms (O4). The 2D layers are connected into a 3D supramolecular network by water heptamers ( ), the geometrical parameters of the hydrogen bonds are given in . In addition to hydrogen bonding, inter-layer contacts are strengthened by intermolecular π-π interactions between adjacent Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(phen)4 units (offset π-π interaction between phen molecules with a face-to-face distance of 3.47Å and offset angle 36.53°). Interestingly, the water heptamers and sulfonate anions are interconnected into a 2D supramolecular layer with very large rhombic windows (with dimensions of 12.57×17.77Å) through hydrogen bonding ( ). The tetranuclear Cu (II) units are right inside the large rhombic windows between the 2D layers ).

Magnetic studies of complexes 1-2 

The variable temperature magnetic susceptibility of complexes 1 and 2 was measured at 1000G in the temperature range 5-300K. The magnetic behaviors of 1 are depicted in   in the forms of χ M and μeff versus T plots (χ M being the molar magnetic susceptibility). As the temperature is lowered, χ M increases slowly until about 50K, then it dramatically increases at lower temperatures. The data between 300 and 5K can be fit to the Curie-Weiss expression, χ M = C/(T - θ), [C =0.125 g 2∑S(S +1)], with the Curie constant C =1.71cm3 Kmol-1, Weiss constant θ =7.5K and g =2.14. On the other hand, at room temperature the effective magnetic moment (μ eff) equals 3.701 μ B, which is slightly higher than the spin-only value of four uncoupled copper (II) S =1/2 ions (theoretical value for g= 2, μ eff =3.464 μ B). The μ eff value increases gradually until 5K, reaching a value of 4.037 μ B. This feature is characteristic of the presence of significant ferromagnetic interactions between the copper (II) ions . Moreover, the positive sign of the Weiss constant also indicates there exist ferromagnetic interactions between the Cu (II) centers.

The magnetic behavior of complex 2 is shown in   in the forms of χ M and μ eff versus T plots. As the temperature is lowered, χ M increases slowly until about 38K, then it dramatically increases at lower temperatures. The data between 300 and 38K can be fit to the Curie-Weiss expression, χ M = C/(T - θ), [C =0.125 g 2 S(S +1)], with the Curie constant C =0.784cm3 mol-1 K and Weiss constant θ =-0.401K. The effective magnetic moment (μ eff) in 2 decreases slowly from 3.43 μ B at 300K to 3.21 μ B at 55K, and then falls rapidly, reaching 2.46 μ B at 5K. At room temperature the effective magnetic moment (μ eff) equals 3.43 μ B, which is slightly lower than the spin-only value of four uncoupled copper (II) S =1/2 ions (theoretical value for g =2, μ eff =3.46 μ B). These features indicate that there exist anti-ferromagnetic interactions amongst the Cu (II) centers . The difference in the magnetic properties of complexes 1 and 2 is possibly the result of the different intermolecular contacts.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent properties of complexes 3-4 

The solid-state fluorescent spectra of complexes 3 and 4 are depicted in   , respectively. In order to understand the nature of the emission bands of complex 3 and 4, we also investigated the luminescence of the free 2, 2-bipy, phen⋅H2O and H3ssal⋅2H2O ligands in the solid state at room temperature. The emission bands for free phen⋅H2O are at 365, 381, 403 and 437nm (λ exc. =344nm), which may be attributed to the π∗ →π transition (). Similar to free phen⋅H2O, the emission bands for the free 2, 2-bipy ligand, at 390, 413 and 438nm (λ exc. =352nm), are also attributed to the π∗ →π transition (). However, the emission bands for free H3ssal⋅2H2O are mainly located at about 387nm with a shoulder peak at 440nm (H3ssal⋅2H2O: λ exc. =335nm) and are attributed to π∗ → n transitions (). Complex 3 exhibits intense green photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 520nm upon excitation at 347nm (). Compared with the emission spectra of the free 2, 2-bipy and H3ssal⋅2H2O ligands, the band at 520nm for 3 might be assigned to the emission of a ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), similar to reported Cd complexes . Complex 4 displays intense blue photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 440nm upon excitation at 329nm (), compared with the emission spectra of the free phen⋅H2O and H3ssal⋅2H2O ligands, the band at 440nm for 4 is neither LMCT (ligand-to-metal charge transfer) nor MLCT (metal-to-ligand charge transfer) in nature, and tentatively might be assigned to an intraligand fluorescent emission .
